user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 start_time, uint32 interval_time)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    struct itimerspec                   timeout;
    int32                               return_code;
    int                                 status;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *     timebase;

    local       = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);
    timebase    = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, *token);
    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    /* There is only something to do here if we are generating a simulated tick */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        /*
        ** Convert from Microseconds to timespec structures
        */
        memset(&timeout, 0, sizeof(timeout));
        OS_UsecToTimespec(start_time, &timeout.it_value);
        OS_UsecToTimespec(interval_time, &timeout.it_interval);

        /*
        ** Program the real timer
        */
        status = timer_settime(local->host_timerid, 0, /* Flags field can be zero */
                               &timeout,               /* struct itimerspec */
                               NULL);                  /* Oldvalue */

        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error in timer_settime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return_code = OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }
        else if (interval_time > 0)
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_interval.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
        else
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_value.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
    }

    local->reset_flag = (return_code == OS_SUCCESS);
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static void OS_UsecToTimespec(uint32 usecs, struct timespec *time_spec)
{
    if (usecs < 1000000)
    {
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs * 1000);
        time_spec->tv_sec  = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        time_spec->tv_sec  = usecs / 1000000;
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs % 1000000) * 1000;
    }
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
status = timer_settime(local->host_timerid, 0, /* Flags field can be zero */
                               &timeout,               /* struct itimerspec */
                               NULL);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment calls the POSIX system function timer_settime to arm a timer; there is no call to OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl (directly or indirectly) in the shown code. timer_settime programs the kernel timer and does not synchronously invoke the user-space handler, so it does not create a call chain back to OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl. (A violation would only occur if timer_settime were implemented in the same codebase and somehow called back into OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl, directly or through another function, creating recursion.)
